Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Growth of the Tibetan Plateau and Eastern Asia Climate: Clues to Understanding the Hydrological Cycle
Award.AbstractNarration:
For fifty years, the Tibetan Plateau has been recognized as the largest topographic feature that perturbs atmospheric circulation. It serves as an ideal field laboratory for understanding the geodynamic processes that build high terrain. Accordingly, the growth of the plateau should have altered atmospheric circulation and therefore written an evolving paleoclimatic signature not only on eastern Asian regional climates, but on global climate as well. Despite many recent studies, we still do not know precisely when the Tibetan Plateau reached its current dimensions and how it perturbs atmospheric circulation. This project brings together geodynamicists, atmospheric scientists, and paleoclimatologists in a multidisciplinary study of the when and the how.

One of the major goals of the project is to quantify the extent to which Tibet has grown by crustal thickening, by thrust faulting and folding, by flow within the crust that redistributes material there, or by replacement of cold mantle lithosphere with hotter material (all in a state of isostatic equilibrium). Such quantification will take big steps toward the understanding of how high plateaus are built and how continental lithosphere deforms, topics at the forefront of geodynamics.

Determining how Tibet has grown will require determining when crustal shortening and thickening occurred, using basic field methods and modern laboratory techniques, and quantifying paleoaltitudes with new isotopic tools. Applying such paleoaltimetric techniques, however, requires an understanding not only of how the atmosphere transports isotopes, but how the evolving high terrain affected surface temperatures at times in the past.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our primary research objectives for this project are to understand the tectonic evolution and surface uplift history of the western Hoh Xil basin that defines the northern portion of the ~5 km high Tibetan Plateau. This region is extremely remote, and was therefore relatively unstudied. Our goals were to carry out a basin analysis study to understand the ~80 myr ago (Ma) to 20 Ma evolution of this basin in the context of India-Asia collision that occurred ~50 Ma. Our hypothesis is that the Hoh Xil Basin represents the retroarc foreland basin to an Andean scale proto-Tibetan Plateau that formed in response to the subduction of oceanic lithosphere on the leading edge of the Indian plate beneath Asia. By this hypothesis, the northern 1/3rd of the Tibetan Plateau would have been at a low elevation prior to Indian-collision and would have achieved its modern width and high elevation through northward propagation of deformation after the collision of India with Asia.

This work has improved our understanding of the geodynamic processes that form broad, high elevation plateaus in collisional orogenic systems. Basin analysis results in western Hoh Xil show a deep (>3 km) basin that experienced northward thinning and fining away from the Tanggula Thrust System in the Qiangtang terrane south of the basin between ~80 and 50 Ma. This stratigraphic information is complemented by northward paleoflow and sediment sources from south of the basin that support the interpretation that the western Hoh Xil basin represents the retroarc foreland basin to an Andean-scale proto-Tibetan Plateau prior to India-Asia collision. Between ~50 and 47 Ma, after the collision of India with Asia, deformation propagated to the north of the Hoh Xil basin, and the basin was incorporated into the Plateau as an intermontane basin that began receiving significant sediment contributions from the north. The tectonic evolution of the western Hoh Xil basin corresponds in timing with the tectonic events in the eastern Hoh Xil basin, indicating that the lithosphere of the northern Tibetan Plateau behaved similarly throughout the long-term evolution of the plateau, and the regional basin experienced a similar geodynamic evolution from at least late Cretaceous through early Miocene time. The emerging picture from this and other recent studies is that oceanic-continental subduction systems have the ability to form relatively narrow plateaus, but collisional systems provide a unique means for producing broad plateaus associated with far-field deformation that begins at around the time of collision. In additional, this study has provided paleogeographic constraints that have elucidated the long-term climate evolution of Asia and the Tibetan's Plateau's influence on regional and global climate. 

Our study of the isotopic composition of surface waters across the entire Tibetan Plateau reveals that climate, and in particular the amount of rainfall and relative humidity, exert a primary control on d-excess and the isotopic composition of rainfall in this high elevation, continental interior setting. These observations highlight the importance of sub-cloud evaporation in the isotopic evolution of rainfall. Our study also demonstrates that the anomalous patterns of surface water composition can be modelled when sub-cloud evaporation, surface water recycling, and the source of atmospheric vapor is taken into consideration. These results elucidate the applicability of stable isotopes in paleoelevation studies in the northern Tibetan Plateau where Rayleigh distillation is not the primary process that fractionates water isotopes, and demonstrate that in the absence of additional paleoclimate information, uncertainties in paleoelevations are too large to apply these methods.
